source.instructions: Construct code by reordering and indenting the lines.

source.name: unit tests grader 1
source.instructions: Construct a function which returns the largest of the three given arguments. You can change the value of a toggleable element () by clicking.

source.name: variable check grader
source.instructions: Construct a program that swaps the values of variables x and y using the helper variable tmp. You can change the names of the variables () by clicking them.
source.options:
{"vartests":[{"initcode":"x = 0
y=2","code":"","message":"Testing with initial variable values x = 0 and y = 2","variables":{"x":2}},{"initcode":"x = 3
y=4

source.name: line based grader
source.instructions:
Construct a function by drag&dropping and reordering lines from the left to the right. The constructed function should return True if the parameter is True and return False otherwise.

Note: The correct solution is obviously a dumb way to do it. This exercise is merely trying to give an example of a Parson's puzzle with js-parsons, not teach you Python :)

source.name: standard code test all symbols in output
standard code test arguments count in output
standard code test inputs in output
fib simple do not show possible values
free text simple (plain text - no preview)
fib oneOf show possible values
source.text:
place1 or "place1" or place2 or "place2" <<<"place1", ""place1"", "place2", ""place2"">>>
value1 or "value1" or value2 or "value2" <<<"value1", ""value1"", "value2", ""value2"">>>

source.name: fib regex
source.text:
color or colour - <<</colou?r/>>>
from 1 to 100 - <<</^([1-9][0-9]?|100)$/>>>
gmail check - <<</(\W|^)[\w.\-]{0,25}@(gmail)\.com(\W|$)/>>>
start from word "begin" - <<</^begin/>>>
ends with word "end" - <<</end$/>>>
